column5: lol... I was informed that I should keep paddles on my 27 foot sportcraft. I laughed and asked if he really thought I was strong enough to paddle that thing. But... there are two under the bench.
I carry 2 paddles in my 20' boat. I also have 2 bottom-cut-out gallon milk jugs; besides the obvious use, they could be used for bailing. Bill
Take an old CD to use as a flash signaling device in the sunlight. Noticeable at a greater distance than a whistle.

http://www.tc.gc.ca/media/documents/...ty/TP-511e.pdf I searched safe boating guide and found this on the Transport Canada website. Pages 17-19 summarize what you need, page 57 talks about Foriegn boats needing to follow requirements from their country.
I'm traveling to LOTW and going into Canadian waters. The regs I read states I need a throw buoy and flares. My boat is 21 ft. Am I correct? Thanks!!

Yes flares if between 6 and 8 meters and in a body of water where you could be more than a mile off shore. Otherwise just a flashlight. I would hazard a guess that most people on lotw don't carry flares though.
To the best of my knowledge, a US registered boat only needs to meet the US requirements. If you have the proper equipment for where your boat is registered, you should be good to go.
We took 50' of floating rope, a whistle and something else I can't remember right now.
That is my understanding as well.

x3 I had a new boat a few months back and it was not registered when we went up to Eagle Lake. The regs stated that I was required to follow the laws where the boat is registered, so I just had to carry my registration application. They do seem like handy items to have on a remote or large lake. I think I will add them to my rig's toolbox.
No, not a bucket, it was a paddle. In case you lost power they wanted a paddle in the boat I guess.
I think they want you to have a bailing bucket on board as well.

We were told a bailing can or bucket,50 ft floating rope a flashlight and a whistle. I think they wanted one without a ball in it. I think I will use coffee cans this year and be done with it. We always break one of the bailers every year.
